Text:
A silhouette moves about in the dimly-lit room.
It pulls several volumes from the bookshelves,
then tosses them on the floor and sets them
alight.

The small fire gradually consumes the books and
lights the chamber up brightly.
What's with the getup, Assistant Principal Lutheran?
*gasp*

Sir Gaunt had thought he was alone in the room,
but now there is a lone boy there with him.

The boy is sitting on the windowsill reading a book.
He has black hair and seems average in every way.

However, he never gives so much as a glance at the
flames spreading behind the man, instead keeping
his gaze on the thick tome in his hands. The sound
of pages turning seems exceptionally loud.
Cid Kagenou...

Sir Gaunt removes his mask, revealing the face of a
middle-aged man.
...How did you know?

The man with his graying hair combed back is none
other than Assistant Principal Lutheran Barnett.
It was easy enough to see.

...Ah, yes. Perhaps it was my gait or my posture.
You have sharp eyes.

Lutheran casts his mask into the flames, his black
cloak following it as well.
The room grows that much brighter.

His eyes are on Cid, and Cid's eyes are on his book.
Their shadows waver in the light of the blaze.
Can I ask you something for my own reference?
And what might that be?

Why? You don't strike me as the type to be
interested in this sort of thing.

Why, you ask? I once stood at the pinnacle of
swordsmanship. Before you were even born.
I did hear you once won the Bushin Festival.

Hah, the Bushin Festival... The true pinnacle lies
much further beyond. Though I suppose you wouldn't
understand.

Lutheran laughs. His laughter has a tone that is
both mocking yet somehow weary.

But no sooner had I reached the top than was I beset
by illness. All my hard-earned glory, gone in an
instant...

I began searching for some means of curing myself...
and then came across a potential answer in the form
of a certain artifact.
Sounds like I'm in for a long story.

Yes, a little. The one studying this artifact was
Sherry's mother. An unfortunate woman despised among
academic circles for the crime of being too clever.

I gave her my support, and she delved into her
research. It was a good relationship.

And then at last I came across just the artifact I
had been seeking.

But that foolish woman declared the Eye of Avarice
too dangerous and even starting spouting nonsense
about giving it to the nation for safekeeping of all
thingsâ€¦
So I killed her.

I started by piercing her extremities and then worked
my way inward...
And in the end, I stabbed her through the heart...
and twisted the blade.

Hehe...hehehe... Sherry never knew, never even
suspected a thing. She simply picked up where her
mother had left off like a good girl.

Completely unaware that it was I who caused all her
pain... Ah, my dear, dear dunce of a daughter.
Lutheran chuckles with a sneer.
Well? Is that enough "reference" for you?

For the most part...but there's just one last detail
I need to know.
And that is...?
Is it true that you were only using Sherry?
Of course I was. Does that make you angry?

I'm not so sure... You see, I draw a clear line between
things that matter to me and those that don't.

Over the course of our lives, we all accumulate
things that matter to us, like friends, lovers, or
jobs... But I've actually done the opposite and rid
myself of all that.

But at the end of that process, I found there was one
thing I couldn't let go of.

So aside from that, I pretty much couldn't care less
about anything else.

So the fates of this naive mother and daughter don't
matter to you one bit?
Cid closes the book.

He gets to his feet and tosses the book into
the flames.

Shall we get this started? If we waste any more time,
someone may come barging in.
Yes. Sadly, we must part.
